structure.title: BEAUTY IS IN THE EYE OF BEHOLDER: INTRACULTURAL AND TRANSCULTURAL HETEROGENEITY OF INDIVIDUALS
structure.author: BY KAMAL FATEHI AND JENNIFER L. PRIESTLEY| HUTZSCHENREUTER, T., KLEINDIENST, I., & LANGE, S. (2019)

sections.title: Abstract and Cultural Theory
sections.content:
The cultural theory discussed in the paper is “Mindscape Theory”, proposed by Magoroh Maruyama, where he defines ". . . a structure of reasoning, cognition, perception, conceptualization, design, planning, and decision making that may vary from one individual, profession, culture, or social group to another“. The core tenets of Mindscape Theory include intracultural heterogeneity, transcultural heterogeneity and dominance of certain types. Mindscape Theory is proposed as a critique of the common assumption of intracultural homogeneity prevalent in many cross-cultural studies, particularly those following the framework of Hofstede, which explains how cultural values differ between countries by identifying six dimensions, such as individualism vs. collectivism and power distance. In high power distance cultures, 
people tend to accept authority and hierarchy, so leaders are expected to make decisions without much input. In individualistic cultures, people value independence and personal achievement, 
while collectivist cultures emphasize group harmony and loyalty. The connection between mindscape theory and beauty is that aesthetic preferences are used as a way to capture and understand the different mindscape types within and between cultures.

sections.title: Sample: 220 Undergraduate Students
sections.content: Across 6 Countries: France, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Peru, South Korea, and the United States. The geographical diversity of the sample included Europe, the Middle East, Central Asia, South America, the Far East, and North America.

sections.title: Methods
sections.content:
1) Factor analysis was used on individual responses to identify underlying patterns in the aesthetic ratings of the geometric shapes, aiming to ascertain if representations of mindscape types were present. 2) Pictorial-Geometric Survey (TOB Tests): Participants from six countries were asked to rate each of the 42 patterns on 
a scale from 1 (ugly) to 7 (beautiful). 3) Heterogram Analysis: Construction of a correlation matrix based on the responses of all participants from the six countries 
on the ugly-beauty scale.

sections.title: Results and Conclusion
sections.content:
The assumption of intracultural homogeneity is questionable. Many traditional cross cultural studies wrongly assume that members of a culture are largely homogeneous in their thinking and logic. This study provides empirical evidence for the existence of significant individual differences within cultures (intracultural heterogeneity). Additionally, the "ugly" to "beautiful" rating scale might be interpreted differently across cultures. The findings support ¹Maruyama's Mindscape Theory, which posits that individual differences in thinking and logic exist 
both within and between cultures.

structure.title: Fashion & Identity: A cross cultural study between South Korea and Mongolia
structure.author: Sun Young Choi, Jeyeon Jo, Yuri Lee, Jisoo Ha & Joeun Lee

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: This study explores cultural differences in how millennial women from South Korea and Mongolia associate clothing with their self-identity. It highlights contrasting fashion perceptions between a global fashion leader and an understudied market.

sections.title: Key Results
sections.content: The study surveyed 441 female university students aged 20–30. South Korean women were found to use fashion as a tool for self-expression and individuality, influenced by trends and social media. In contrast, Mongolian women view fashion as a reflection of tradition and social norms, often shaped by cultural heritage. South Korean fashion aligns with values of individualism and indulgence, whereas Mongolian fashion emphasizes collectivism and restraint. These insights suggest that fashion brands should tailor their strategies based on cultural values rather than using a one-size-fits-all approach.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.content: The study used a quantitative research approach, gathering data through structured questionnaires from 441 female university students aged 20 to 30. Participants included 179 South Korean and 262 Mongolian millennials. Statistical comparison techniques were employed to analyze cultural attitudes and fashion-related behavior. The survey was designed to examine how young women in both countries connect fashion to their self-identity, considering cultural and societal influences.

sections.title: Cultural Theory
sections.content: Geert Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions Theory provides the framework for interpreting the cultural differences in fashion values between South Korea and Mongolia. South Korean society reflects higher levels of individualism and indulgence, which manifests in fashion as trend-driven, expressive, and self-identity focused. In contrast, Mongolia leans toward collectivism and restraint, where fashion is shaped by tradition, cultural heritage, and social expectations. These cultural dimensions influence how women in each country perceive and use clothing — as either a form of personal expression or as a reflection of collective values and continuity.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: The study concludes that fashion is deeply influenced by cultural values, and that the perception and use of clothing vary significantly between South Korea and Mongolia. South Korean fashion prioritizes individuality and identity, influenced by global trends and media. In contrast, Mongolian fashion is more conservative, reflecting cultural tradition and social harmony. For fashion marketers, these findings underscore the importance of culturally tailored branding strategies and the risks of applying a one-size-fits-all approach to global audiences.

structure.title:
“Comparison of Senior Leisure Activities in China and 
the United States from the Perspective of Cultural Differences”
structure.author: Shuang Yang, Sheling Ye, Haiyan Li (2022)

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Cultural values strongly influence how older adults spend their free time. This poster compares daily leisure patterns among adults aged 55 and over in China and the United States, examining how factors like independence, family ties, and tradition shape indoor and outdoor activities.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.content: For the purpose of this research a cross-cultural comparison was conducted using two distinct data sources to analyze leisure preferences among older adults. Primary data was collected in China via questionnaires in three communities in Hangzhou. In contrast, U.S. data was sourced from the American Time Use Survey (ATUS), a nationally representative dataset.
sections.imageExplanation: Table 1: The chart illustrates the significant difference in sample sizes between the two countries. While China relied on a local sample of 192 individuals, the United States used national data from ATUS, representing tens of thousands of participants.
sections.limitations: A major limitation is the difference in sample size and data collection methods. The Chinese sample appears to be small and localized, whereas the US data are large and nationally representative. As a result, direct comparisons should be made with caution, and findings should be interpreted as descriptive rather than statistically equivalent.

sections.title: Key Results
sections.content: The key findings highlight both similarities and differences in leisure activities between China and the United States. In both countries, watching TV is the most common indoor activity, while walking is the most frequent outdoor activity. However, there are distinct cultural differences. In China, leisure time often involves traditional group activities such as Taiji, sword dancing, and mahjong. Additionally, 23.4% of seniors in China use the internet, and leisure tends to be family-oriented and commonly takes place in community spaces. In contrast, in the United States, leisure is more focused on individual hobbies and physical activities like reading, going to the gym, or playing golf. There is also a strong emphasis on structured self-care and personal development, with greater value placed on independence than on community life.

sections.title: Implications
sections.content: Leisure behavior in later life reflects cultural values. These findings suggest elderly services should adapt to cultural contexts. In China, fostering autonomy may enhance well-being, while in the U.S., promoting family- and community-based activities could strengthen social ties. Culturally informed planning is key to inclusive leisure programs.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: While seniors in both countries prefer walking and watching television, their motivations differ: American seniors seek independence, while Chinese seniors value family connection and tradition. Recognizing these patterns is essential for designing leisure initiatives that respect cultural differences and support diverse ageing needs.

structure.title: Housing as a Reflection of Culture: Privatised Living and Privacy in England and Japan
structure.author: Ritsuko Ozaki (2002)

sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Houses are not just physical spaces but reflect cultural values through their layout, shaping social interactions, daily rituals and ideas of privacy. Focusing on England (Bracknell) and Japan (Kohoku New Town), this cross-cultural study examines how privatised living influences housing design.

sections.title: Key Results
sections.content: In England, housing design strongly reflects a focus on personal privacy and individual expression. This is evident in features such as en-suite bathrooms, individual bedrooms for each resident, and functional additions like utility rooms, garden sheds, and guest toilets. The home is viewed as a private retreat, with front gardens left open and visible, while the main garden at the back offers seclusion for residents. In contrast, Japanese homes emphasize family privacy and shared living, often featuring large, multi-purpose areas that combine kitchen, dining, and living spaces to promote warmth and togetherness. Gardens are designed for calm and atmosphere rather than activity, and houses are typically enclosed by fences to protect family privacy. Although the cultural focus remains on familial closeness, personal privacy has become more important in recent decades, as reflected in the growing adoption of Western-style bedrooms—from just 17% in the 1970s to 66% by the 1990s.

sections.title: Methodology
sections.content: The study employed both quantitative and qualitative research methods. Quantitative analysis was based on the examination of house floor plans and furnishings, with a sample size of 146 in England and 123 in Japan. Statistical techniques such as T-tests, ANOVA, and Chi-square tests were used to analyze the data. On the qualitative side, structured interviews were conducted with 56 homeowners in England and 55 in Japan. These interviews included four key open-ended questions, addressing topics such as the ideal home and individual preferences or dislikes. The responses were systematically coded into 20 thematic categories, including privacy, space, family, and aesthetics.

sections.title: Cultural Theory
sections.content: Geert Hofstede’s Cultural Dimensions Theory highlights cultural differences in the concept of privacy. Cultural attitudes toward privacy differ notably between England and Japan. In England, where individualism is strongly valued, there is a high emphasis on personal privacy, which is understood as having one’s own self-contained space. In contrast, Japan’s collectivistic culture, shaped by Confucian values, places greater importance on shared spaces and familial privacy. Here, privacy is defined less by individual separation and more by the intimacy and closeness within the family environment. Cultural attitudes toward privacy differ notably between England and Japan. In England, where individualism is strongly valued, there is a high emphasis on personal privacy, which is understood as having one’s own self-contained space. In contrast, Japan’s collectivistic culture, shaped by Confucian values, places greater importance on shared spaces and familial privacy. Here, privacy is defined less by individual separation and more by the intimacy and closeness within the family environment.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content:
The paper highlights how housing styles in England and Japan are deeply
influenced by social and cultural values — especially differing ideas about
privacy and family life.
While practical factors like climate, building techniques and cost do play a role in shaping homes, they are seen more as secondary influences rather than the main drivers of design.
The distinct cultural views on personal space and privacy are clearly
reflected in the way homes are laid out, showing just how closely connected architecture is to the culture it comes from.

structure.title: Mental health literacy: a cross-cultural approach to knowledge and beliefs about depression, schizophrenia and generalized anxiety disorder
structure.author: Laura Altweck, Tara C. Marshall, Nelli Ferenczi and Katharina Lefringhausen

sections.title: Introduction/Theory
sections.content:
•Based on Hofstede‘s cultural dimensions (indivisualism vs. collectivism)
•
Mental Health Literacy (MHL) =
Knowledge and beliefs about mental disorders that help recognition, management, prevention
•
Focus on:
Depression, Schizophrenia, Generalized Anxiety Disorder
•
Importance:
Understanding how cultural context

sections.title: Research Questions
sections.content:
•How do MHL components differ between individualistic (USA) and
collectivistic (India) cultures?
•
How does collectivism predict beliefs about causes and help-seeking?

sections.title: Methods
sections.content:
Participants:
USA (N = 100, European Americans)
India (N = 108, Indians)
Measures:
•
Vignettes describing mental health symptoms
Scale measuring:
•
Recognition
•
Causal beliefs (social vs. biological)
•
Lay help-seeking beliefs (family, friends, religious leaders)
•
Professional help-seeking beliefs (GPs,

sections.title: Key Results
sections.content:
Recognition
USA participants are better at identifying mental disorders
than Indian participants
Causal Beliefs
•
Both cultures emphasized social causes over biological ones
•
Biological causes are less relevant in the Indian sample
Help-Seeking Beliefs
India: Strong reliance on lay help (family, community, religious figures)
USA: More direct focus on professional help
Collectivism effects:
•
In India collectivism predicts lay help-seeking
•
In the USA collectivism predicts stronger social causal beliefs
Statistical Insights
•
Recognition predicts more positive professional help-seeking
•
In India, lay help-seeking mediates between collectivism and
professional help

sections.title: Cultural Pathways to Help-Seeking in India
Conclusion
sections.content:
This study shows that cultural context significantly shapes mental health literacy. In India, collectivism fosters reliance on lay help, which facilitates eventual professional help-seeking, while in the USA, collectivism
mainly reinforces social causal beliefs, with more direct paths to
professional services. Recognition of mental disorders emerges as a key factor for positive help-seeking attitudes across both cultures.
These findings highlight the need for culturally sensitive mental health
interventions that strengthen family and community networks in
collectivistic societies and improve access to
professional services in individualistic ones. By addressing these
culturally specific pathways, stigma can be reduced, and access to mental health care can be enhanced globally.

structure.title: Cross-Cultural Influence in Sports Behavior and Coaching
structure.author: - Carrington, B. (2015). Football, Identity – Japan & UK- Anderson & Li (2022). Coaching – Germany & China

sections.title: Cultural Theories
sections.content: Sport is a global language—but how it is played, taught, and celebrated varies across cultures. Cross-cultural research helps us understand motivation, teamwork, leadership, and athlete development in global sport environments.

sections.title: Participant Sample
sections.content: 220 partipants: Yorth athletes (14-22), Coaches (25-60), Media experts Countries: Germany, China, Japan, UK, USA, divese cultural backgrounds,

sections.title: Methods
sections.content: Surveys, interviews, training observation, media analysis. Cruss-cultural comparative design with thematic evaluation. A mixed-methods approach was used. Surveys gethered athlete perceptions; interviews revealed coaching strategies and cultural sensitivity. Observations in practice sessions and media analysis showed how culture influences communication and leadership.

sections.title: Reflective Loop & Synthesis
sections.content: Wath work in one culture might not in another. Reflctive leads to improved coaching steategies & intercultural awareness. A mixed-methods approach was used.
